abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental management
            framework for the Capacity Building for Decentralized
            Service Delivery Project for Ethiopia, which finances pilot
            investments for infrastructure rehabilitation to facilitate
            a learning-by-doing approach and to test the feasibility of
            larger scale infrastructure investment components in future
            operations. This report anticipates that soil and water
            contamination, vegetation loss, soil erosion, dust, noise,
            and accidents during rehabilitation activities will be
            possible negative environmental impacts from sub-projects.
            Sections of this report illustrate the specific steps
            financial intermediaries will take in screening sub-projects
            for environmental impacts and assigning them in the
            appropriate environmental category. To determine the depth
            of detail of the environmental impact assessment, the
            potential impacts in the following areas will be considered:
            social considerations such as tradition and sociao
            organization, tenure rights, predominant attitudes toward
            growth, patterns of interactions, and capacity of local
            institutions; health issues; protected areas; cultural
            heritage and archaeological sites; existing natural
            resources such as forests, soils, wetlands, and water
            resources; and wildlife or endangered species' habitats.
